channel.title: Apache Rewrite rule
channel.description:
I am using a rewrite rule on a website that has dynamic content and uses seofriendly page names
RewriteRule ^category/([^/]*)\.html$ /category.php?route=$1 [L]
I've recently have added an optional feature that may or may not include a GET header. I dont' want to force something like
category/param1/param2/ as it will distort my analytics and would prefer the routing to go as follows:
category/param1.html&remainingparamters -> category.php?route=$1&$2
do I have a way of combining all parameters after the .html as $2 for the rewrite rule?

item.title: Apache Rewrite rule
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

QSA does appear to do exactly what I need so thanks!

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Rewrite rule
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

You can pass through all the original parameters with QSA - http://wiki.apache.org/httpd/RewriteFlags/QSA

which would get rewritten like this:
/category/cars.html -> category.php?category=cars
/category/cars.html&category=suv&category=sedan -> category.php?category=cars&category=suv&category=sedan

disclaimer: not sure if php actually supports parameters with the same name… probably not coz php is shit

Read full topic

item.title: Apache Rewrite rule
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

I am using a rewrite rule on a website that has dynamic content and uses seofriendly page names

RewriteRule ^category/([^/]*).html$ /category.php?route=$1 [L]

I’ve recently have added an optional feature that may or may not include a GET header. I dont’ want to force something like

category/param1/param2/ as it will distort my analytics and would prefer the routing to go as follows:

category/param1.html&remainingparamters -> category.php?route=$1&$2

do I have a way of combining all parameters after the .html as $2 for the rewrite rule?

Read full topic
